skill.name: pydeseq2
skill.description: Differential gene expression analysis (Python DESeq2). Identify DE genes from bulk RNA-seq counts, Wald tests, FDR correction, volcano/MA plots, for RNA-seq analysis.
skill.summary: Differential gene expression analysis (Python DESeq2). Identify DE genes from bulk RNA-seq counts, W...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: All 429 static findings are false positives. The 'weak cryptographic algorithm' flags incorrectly match 'DES' in 'DESeq2' (a statistical method name, not cryptography). The 'external_commands' flags misinterpret markdown code fences as shell execution. Filesystem access is standard data I/O for bioinformatics workflows. Network access involves only documentation URLs. This is a legitimate scientific computing skill with no malicious code.

content.user_title: Analyze RNA-seq differential gene expression with PyDESeq2
content.value_statement: PyDESeq2 enables differential gene expression analysis from bulk RNA-seq count data. Perform statistical testing, multiple comparison correction, and generate publication-ready volcano and MA plots for your genomics research.
actual_capabilities: Load and validate RNA-seq count matrices from CSV or TSV files
Perform DESeq2 normalization, dispersion fitting, and statistical testing
Execute Wald tests with automatic multiple testing correction
Apply apeGLM log fold change shrinkage for visualization
Generate volcano and MA plots for result visualization
Export results as CSV files for downstream analysis
limitations: Requires count matrix in samples Ã— genes orientation (transpose if needed)
Minimum 10 total counts per gene recommended for filtering
Designed for bulk RNA-seq data, not single-cell applications

use_cases.title: Compare treated vs control
use_cases.description: Identify differentially expressed genes between experimental conditions using proper statistical testing and FDR correction for publication-ready results.

use_cases.title: RNA-seq thesis analysis
use_cases.description: Process RNA-seq count data, perform differential expression analysis, and generate publication-quality figures for thesis or research papers.

use_cases.title: Batch RNA-seq processing
use_cases.description: Automate differential expression analysis across multiple conditions or timepoints using the included command-line script.

prompt_templates.title: Basic DE analysis
prompt_templates.scenario: User has count and metadata files
prompt_templates.prompt: Load my RNA-seq data from counts.csv and metadata.csv, then perform differential expression analysis comparing treated vs control samples using PyDESeq2

prompt_templates.title: Multi-factor design
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze my RNA-seq data accounting for batch effects using design formula ~batch + condition, then test for treatment vs control differences

prompt_templates.title: Generate visualizations
prompt_templates.prompt: Run PyDESeq2 analysis on my data and create volcano and MA plots highlighting significant genes with padj < 0.05

prompt_templates.title: Advanced filtering
prompt_templates.prompt: Load RNA-seq data, filter genes with fewer than 20 total counts, use multi-factor design ~age + sex + condition, and identify genes with |log2FC| > 1 and padj < 0.01

output_examples.input: Analyze my RNA-seq data and show top differentially expressed genes

best_practices: Always transpose count matrix if genes are rows (use .T to get samples Ã— genes format)
Filter low-count genes before analysis to improve statistical power
Use adjusted p-values (padj) not raw p-values for determining significance
Check that sample names match exactly between counts and metadata files
anti_patterns: Never use raw p-values for multiple testing - always use FDR-corrected padj values
Do not apply LFC shrinkage before statistical testing - use after for visualization only
Avoid complex multi-factor designs without sufficient sample size per condition
Never transpose metadata - only transpose count matrix if needed

faq.question: Why do I get an index mismatch error?
faq.answer: Sample names in counts and metadata files do not match. Ensure both files use identical sample identifiers in the same format.

faq.question: Should I transpose my count matrix?
faq.answer: If your CSV has genes as rows and samples as columns, transpose with .T to get the required samples Ã— genes format.

faq.question: What is the difference between pvalue and padj?
faq.answer: pvalue is the raw statistical p-value; padj is the FDR-corrected value for multiple testing. Use padj < 0.05 for significance.

faq.question: When should I use LFC shrinkage?
faq.answer: Apply LFC shrinkage after statistical testing for visualization, ranking genes, or creating heatmaps. Do not use for significance determination.

faq.question: How do I handle batch effects in my analysis?
faq.answer: Include batch in your design formula as ~batch + condition. This controls for technical variation while testing biological differences.

faq.question: Why are no genes significant in my analysis?
faq.answer: Check your sample size, effect sizes, and biological variability. Small studies or subtle effects may yield few significant genes.
